1450856284882886663.text: WATCH: I'm joining @MitchellReports around 12:15 to discuss the #FreedomToVoteAct and the importance of protecting our democracy.

1450622942262579202.text: Our democracy faces a crisis that requires action. Now is the moment to reach beyond region, beyond party, beyond self, to save and reinvigorate the sputtering flame of the American idea. That is why we must pass the #FreedomToVoteAct. https://t.co/WnuPIcK16r

1450600965128732673.text: The American experiment in self-government is a fragile anomaly in world history – and at this moment, we are facing profoundly dangerous threats to this system. I’m LIVE on the Senate floor, arguing for action to defend and restore our democracy. Watch: https://t.co/ZPVTIlTLf1

1450582616843952129.text: Right now, the very idea of America – the sacred idea of government of the people, by the people, and for the people – is under threat. 1352300196055683075.text: TUNE IN: ~ 12:05, I’ll join @mitchellreports to discuss the first days of the new Administration and the transition. I look forward to working with a bipartisan group of colleagues and @POTUS to help the American people, revive our economy, and unify our nation.

1351947996494233606.text: As President Lincoln said: it’s time to rise with the occasion.

1351947995546345476.text: I believe that President Biden has the opportunity, the ability, and the character to unify our nation and make this government work for its people. Now, Congress must do its part, and come together on a bipartisan basis to improve the country we all love so dearly.

1351947994527100930.text: More than 150 years later, it’s impossible to summarize this moment in American history, or the proper response, any better than Lincoln did. It’s time to think anew, and act anew, because we cannot allow our usual petty squabbles to hinder our response to the threats we face.

1351947993394671623.text: He said: ‘The dogmas of the quiet past are inadequate to the stormy present. The occasion is piled high with difficulty and we must rise with the occasion. As our case is new, we must think anew and act anew. We must disenthrall ourselves, and then we shall save our country.’

1351947989623992322.text: At this urgent juncture, I find myself turning to the words one of our nation’s greatest citizens. As President Abraham Lincoln worked to preserve the Union during its most delicate time, he urged Congress to rise to the moment.

1351947988432781322.text: A divided nation, where a few conflict-seeking voices on the fringes seem to drown out the majority who long for compromise. In the middle of these crises and more, we cannot simply settle into business-as-usual.

1351947985479938048.text: Our nation is facing immense challenges. A pandemic that has already killed nearly 400,000 Americans, and still grows worse by the day. A foundering economy that is forcing too many Americans to make unimaginable choices.

1351947980673323009.text: Through it all, the flame of democracy was protected by generations of patriots, public servants, and everyday citizens who put the long-term health of the nation ahead of short-term personal gain. Now, it is our turn to do the same.

1351947979708653572.text: For nearly a quarter of a millennium, American government of the people, by the people, for the people has endured. This lasting success was not pre-ordained; our experiment in self-government has had to contend with wars and diseases, economic depressions and internal divisions.

1351160562877681669.text: Today, we honor Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., who spoke with clarity passion, and unparalleled talent to remind all who would hear him of the American promise that it’s character that counts, not race, religion, or national origin. 1237807572788350982.text: If you’d like to hear more about the Commission’s findings or process, we are about to launch our report at an event moderated by @IgnatiusPost. The event is being livestreamed, and you can watch here: https://t.co/OIYWIHOI3G

1237807141647417344.text: One last note: our report is *completely unclassified* because improving cybersecurity can’t just happen behind closed doors in Washington. It requires work from each of us. I hope you’ll give it a read, and urge your elected officials to act on cyber before it’s too late.

1237806911455723523.text: These are just a few of our recommendations – and by no means is our list exhaustive. We concluded some debates without reaching a consensus, and in this ever-shifting sphere there will be new challenges to face that we can’t yet imagine. But this is a very good place to start.

1237806632131756033.text: ➡️We need the American people to be able to stay vigilant, and that starts with helping them understand foreign interference. The government should support digital literacy, civics education, and public awareness of malign foreign efforts.

1237806390888017921.text: ➡️The team at @CISAGov is doing important work already, and we need to elevate their efforts by giving the agency the authorities and funding it needs to reach its full potential.

1237806045755572224.text: ➡️Congress should establish a Senate-confirmed National Cyber Director within the executive branch. With cyber touching so many aspects of our lives (and government), we need someone at the highest level who can wrangle all the federal agencies to move the ball forward.

1237805860761620487.text: ➡️Congress should create House Permanent Select and Senate Select Committees. Right now, cyber responsibility is diluted across committees, creating a sometimes insurmountable obstacle to progress. We can’t let Congressional bureaucracy impede necessary action.

1237805569089712140.text: To help enact these layers, we’ve created six pillars of deterrence and more than 75 specific recommendations focused on improving security in both the public and private sectors. Some of our key findings:

1237805300842782720.text: There is no silver bullet here, but there may be silver buckshot. America needs to pursue layered cyber deterrence by enhancing our defenses at home, reducing benefits for those who would try to exploit our cyber vulnerabilities, and imposing costs for those who cross the line.

1237805188511084544.text: The CSC brought together bipartisan Members of Congress – including my co-chair @RepGallagher, @SenSasse, and @JimLangevin – top executive branch officials, and industry leaders, drawing from the different perspectives we need to face this pressing challenge head on.

1237803410528894976.text: To be blunt: we are dangerously insecure in cyberspace, even as we become more reliant on it. Everything from your bank account to your health records to your electricity relies on cyber; but America has serious vulnerabilities that, when exploited, inflict lasting damage.

1237802651322068992.text: For a year, the @CyberSolarium has worked to review the threats America faces in cyberspace and provide recommendations on how to address them. Today, we’re releasing our report, which we hope will help guide the country in the years ahead. Read: https://t.co/ViDnPftEuG

1237782256267247622.text: Today at 1 p.m., I’ll be joining @MaineCalling (and some of you!) to discuss the @CyberSolarium, which is releasing our report today. Call in with questions about the threats we face and ways we can protect ourselves. Listen here: https://t.co/ogdLfBRq9j

1237700970706079744.text: At ~7:40, I’ll join @NewDay to discuss today’s @CyberSolarium report and the Commission’s recommendations to restore deterrence in cyberspace.

1219667932617281537.text: If I have one bit of advice for my Senate colleagues, it is this: the truth will come out in all of this, and we will be judged on whether we sought it or sought to avoid it. I sincerely hope that our body can rise to this task, and live up to our commitment to impartial justice.

1219667931161858048.text: As we approach today’s votes, my colleagues and I face a stark choice: we can either commit to a fair trial that focuses on getting the truth, or endorse a flawed process that attempts to undermine our work before it’s even begun.

1219667929215664128.text: It is more obvious than ever that this is not just a trial in the Senate – it is a trial *of* the Senate.

1219667926829142017.text: For weeks, Senator McConnell has been telling everyone who would listen that the Senate’s impeachment process would use the rules that governed the Clinton impeachment – but it is clear today that his assertions were at best misleading, and at worst, a willful bait and switch.

1047195101817176064.text: Both of these bipartisan efforts will make sure we leave our public lands in pristine condition for our children, just as our parents did for us. These efforts may not break through some of the political noise, but that doesn’t make the work any less important.

1038861063301857280.text: People with substance use disorders can recover and lead happy, healthy lives of service and productivity, if they have the proper support systems. That support system must include us – all of us – and that is why today’s event is so important.

1021802324019294209.text: Our electric grid touches every part of our society; an attack disabling it could have catastrophic results. Can you imagine what would happen if the power went out for days? Weeks?

1021802321058189314.text: For years, I’ve worked with my colleague @SenatorRisch on a bipartisan bill to protect our energy grid from foreign attacks by implementing manual features to prevent hackers from remotely shutting down key infrastructure – it's commonsense, and it's important.

1011969008294342657.text: Maine’s farmers are the backbone of our state, and their products are second-to-none; whether it’s legislation or a letter, I’ll keep fighting for programs like this to ensure they have every opportunity to grow and thrive.

1011969006662766596.text: It’s just common sense – if something works, invest in it! That’s why I introduced the CREAATE Act to double the funding for both MAP and FMD over the next five years and make sure American farmers can compete in the global marketplace.

1011969005085773826.text: MAP and FMD are wildly successful: for every dollar spent, they return $28.30 (!) to our economy. But despite this impact, their funding has remained stagnant for more than a decade.

1011969002166542336.text: This week, I led 13 of my colleagues in a letter urging the Agriculture Committee to increase funding for the Market Access Program and Foreign Market Development Program – two programs that help farmers access new global markets. https://t.co/rriTgnCXuk

1011689849685008385.text: Today I urged the nominee for the top cybersecurity job at the Department of Energy to push the Administration to prioritize cyber defense – including re-establishing a role to coordinate between agencies, and formulating a cyber doctrine of deterrence. 1010657571684921344.text:
No words can fully convey the depth of our respect for Gold Star families, but now Brunswick is home to a memorial that marks our commitment to easing their grief and honoring their loved ones. Earlier today I was humbled to help dedicate this sacred site.
https://t.co/1o7A4qhWvA

1009823816032378881.text: The idea that the Administration would reverse its policy of family separation to show "compassion" but not attempt to return the 2000+ children who have already been taken makes no sense. These kids still need their parents, and should be reunited with them immediately.

1009548462340308992.text: This move is overdue but far from a long-term fix. I’ve heard from thousands of Maine people on this subject and I know that, we as a Nation, can find a way to both protect our border and protect children and families seeking asylum.

1009548459349889024.text: I’m glad that the President finally recognized two important facts about his family separation policy: first, this crisis was unnecessary and he has the power to correct it on his own; second, separating children from their parents is incongruent with American values.

1009093510069448704.text: These kids are not bargaining chips – they are kids. And they should be with their parents. Mr. President: make the call, and end this policy. https://t.co/Sfnb5HG6yX

1009093307178323968.text: The Administration’s policy of separating families at the border is simply wrong, and could be solved today by a phone call from the President to the Attorney General. Last night, I spoke on the Senate floor against this cruel policy. You can watch part 1 of my remarks here…. https://t.co/UmJWuP5EAG

1008815167168270337.text: Speaking on the Senate floor to urge the Administration to end its policy of family separation. WATCH LIVE: https://t.co/mNZScJv0g4

1006612634186240003.text:
If you or someone you know is suffering, know that you are not alone. To get help, call the National Suicide Hotline: 1-800-273-8255 (TALK) or text TALK to 741741. 

You are a valuable member of our state and our society – please, stay with us another day and let us try to help.

1006612632734961666.text: The biggest message these advocates shared is the importance of destigmatizing suicide by facilitating safe and open conversation about risk factors and statistics. Suicide victims are our family members, friends, and neighbors – and they need our help.

1006612630906253319.text: Today, I met with Maine representatives of the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention (@afspnational) to discuss life-saving solutions – because, with suicide rates in Maine up 27.4% in the last 20 years, there is much work to be done to improve access to mental health care.

1006612629492830209.text: Suicide has recently been at the forefront of national discussions. But this isn’t a new problem – it’s ongoing, and it’s claiming lives of Maine people while leaving behind devastated families and communities unsure about how to prevent tragedies like this in the future.

1005499439467978753.text: This product is all-natural, but a new FDA proposal might confuse consumers into thinking there are additives. 959538109531729920.text: I will take my cue from these devoted public servants, and focus my efforts on the bipartisan investigation taking place in the Senate Intelligence Committee.

959538103504592896.text: What is clear, however, is that this is an obvious attempt to discredit the work of the men and women at the FBI, whose association reminded us just today that they will continue to do their work to protect America regardless of distractions and partisan politics.

959538098349727745.text: It is nearly impossible to make a judgment based on a document so clearly partisan, and one that attempts to boil down the extensive information required for FISA applications and renewals into just over three pages.

959538083166384132.text: Through decades in business, public service, and law, I’ve learned over and over again that there are at least two sides to every story, which must be closely considered in uncovering the facts. This memo tells only one side of the story – and a limited version at that.

“Martin Luther King Jr. Day across the country is a day of service, and it made sense to me to start in my hometown.” 
https://t.co/w7ttpfdj2z

952979767141306369.text: So, as we honor him today, let us take the opportunity to follow Dr. King’s legacy and serve – serve our friends and our neighbors, our communities and our country, as we continue to march toward the fulfillment of that radical new dream. #MLKDay

952979045062533121.text: Dr. King’s speech guaranteed that his dream, so deeply rooted in the American Dream, is now and forever embedded in the fabric of our nation. #MLKDay

952979042843717632.text: I had climbed a tree on the National Mall to watch the speech, and from that tree I saw Dr. King light a new path forward for our country with his eloquence, his passion and his conscience. #MLKDay

952979040280956928.text: As his words soared from the steps of the Lincoln Memorial, they were taken in by 250,000 men and women of all races, religions, creeds and ethnicities – including my 19-year-old self. #MLKDay

952979037856698368.text: On August 28, 1963, Martin Luther King Jr. told the world about his radical new dream: that America would fulfill its promise of equality to all citizens, not just the lucky few of the right color. #MLKDay

910976551650504705.text: .…and our next steps on healthcare must to provide them with the aid that they need, not shortchange them. END

910976452992098304.text: I’ll continue to say clearly, and loudly, that our rural hospitals need our help…

910976334930857984.text: So, when I go back to Washington next week to discuss healthcare, I’ll carry the concerns and challenges of Jackman/rural Maine with me.

910976173760540673.text: This impacts everything – a CBP officer told me today they struggle to recruit/keep border patrol personnel due to limited healthcare.

910976013345198081.text: That means that the a mill worker on the late shift, or an elderly citizen who slips and falls, would have to drive over an hour for care.

910975873460908033.text: At the moment, Jackman stands to lose overnight emergency medical services at the end of the year.

910975769832296453.text: Communities need access to close and affordable healthcare in order to thrive.

910975593801555968.text: THREAD: Spent the day talking healthcare in Jackman today. There was one thought that was present in all of my conversations:

910882387260772354.text: Cybercrime costs the global economy hundreds of billions of dollars a year – it’s critical that we protect our networks.

910882031873265664.text: Concerned to hear SEC's database was breached. This is another example of why we need strong cyber defenses.

910652819442737153.text: Jackman is one of many towns with these challenges – they need bipartisan help. Look forward to hearing more tomorrow. (3/3)

910652679965302784.text: Jackman could lose overnight emergency/ambulance care at the end of 2017, forcing residents to drive more than an hour for care. (2/3)

910652552328433664.text: Tomorrow, I’ll be meeting with local leaders in Jackman to discuss the healthcare crisis they, and other rural towns, face. (1/3)
